messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...>
wrote:
>
> C?dric Beust ? wrote:
> >
> >
> > On 8/7/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...
> > <mailto:jbrains762%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> >
> > > > this is what I am trying to avoid. I want to have a single
TestCase
> > > > that is parameterized to run on any given Algorithm
subclass. In your
> > > > example I should create a new TestCase for each Algorighm
subclass.
> > > >
> > > > In practice I have 10 test cases and 10 "Algorithms". The
problem is
> > > > that I don't want to write and support 100 test classes, bu
only 10.
> > >
> > > You could try writing a custom suite() method that looks like
this:
> > >
> > > public static Test suite() {
> > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Algorithm tests");
> > > suite.add(new AlgorithmTest(new Algorithm1()));
> > > ...
> > > suite.add(new AlgorithmTest(new Algorithm99())));
> >
> > This still requires the creation of 100 classes instead of 10,
right?
>
> Production classes, not test case classes. There is one test case
class.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
>

No, it does not require. I tried to do that, but found that JUnit
does not use TestCase instance passed to suite.add() method. It just
direves class name from the instance and them creates a new one to
run test. I might be wrong, but I spent pretty much time and finally
came up with the conslusion above.
